Situation1: The partner received disappointing feedback at work and is visibly upset.
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: A major news network has just called for an immediate on-air comment to counter misinformation in a breaking story.
Story: I sat on the couch, my phone buzzing insistently in my hand. Across from me, Alex slumped forward, his shoulders shaking as he stared at the rejection email on his laptop. He needed me—he’d barely spoken since he got home, and I could see the hurt in his eyes. I wanted to wrap my arms around him, listen, reassure him that he was more than his job. But my phone kept vibrating. The news network was calling, asking for my voice to set the record straight on live TV. Our campaign had worked for months to get this kind of platform, and misinformation was already spreading fast. I could hear the urgency in the producer’s texts: “We need you now.” My heart pounded. Alex’s pain pulled at me, but so did the responsibility to my cause, to everyone counting on me to speak up. I felt torn in two, guilt and anxiety twisting inside me as I looked from Alex’s hunched figure to the glowing screen in my hand, knowing I couldn’t be in both places at once.
